Get started

2021-10-24

Source: vignettes/container.Rmd
container.Rmd

Introduction

The container package is designed to serve three main goals:

  1. enhance base R list for interactive sessions
  2. enhance base R list for code development
  3. provide specialized data structures that are not available with base R

This vignette will cover the first point and present the basic container operations. For the second point see vignette Why and how container for code development. Examples for specialized data structures are found in the vignettes Manage parameter lists with dict and Smartly select and mutate data columns with dict.table.

> library(container)

Basic methods

For easier typing it’s recommended to use the shorter cont when creating container objects in interactive sessions.

> co <- cont(n = 5, data = cars[1:5, ], form = speed ~ dist)

The container print method is designed to be very compact.

> print(co)
[n = 5, data = <<data.frame(5x2)>>, form = <<formula>>]

For more verbose output, either convert to a base list …

> as.list(co)
$n
[1] 5

$data
  speed dist
1     4    2
2     4   10
3     7    4
4     7   22
5     8   16

$form
speed ~ dist

or use str.

> str(co)
Container of 3 
 $ n   : num 5
 $ data:'data.frame':   5 obs. of  2 variables:
  ..$ speed: num [1:5] 4 4 7 7 8
  ..$ dist : num [1:5] 2 10 4 22 16
 $ form:Class 'formula'  language speed ~ dist
  .. ..- attr(*, ".Environment")=<environment: R_GlobalEnv>

Both length and names work as usual.

> length(co)
[1] 3
> names(co)
[1] "n"    "data" "form"
> names(co)[1] <- "a"
> co
[a = 5, data = <<data.frame(5x2)>>, form = <<formula>>]

There is also an alternative way for renaming.

> co = rename(co, old = c("a", "form"), new = c("N", "ff"))
> co
[N = 5, data = <<data.frame(5x2)>>, ff = <<formula>>]

A container can also be constructed from a list.

> l = list(x = 1:2, y = (1:2)^2)
> co2 = as.container(l)
> co2
[x = (1L 2L), y = (1 4)]

Add elements

Elements can be added by concatenation

> c(co, co2)
[N = 5, data = <<data.frame(5x2)>>, ff = <<formula>>, x = (1L 2L), y = (1 4)]

or name.

> co[["co2"]] <- co2
> co
[N = 5, data = <<data.frame(5x2)>>, ff = <<formula>>, co2 = [x = (1L 2L), y = (1 4)]]

As you see containers can be nested. To flatten everything into a list, use unpack.

> str(unpack(co))
List of 16
 $ N          : num 5
 $ data.speed1: num 4
 $ data.speed2: num 4
 $ data.speed3: num 7
 $ data.speed4: num 7
 $ data.speed5: num 8
 $ data.dist1 : num 2
 $ data.dist2 : num 10
 $ data.dist3 : num 4
 $ data.dist4 : num 22
 $ data.dist5 : num 16
 $ ff         :Class 'formula'  language speed ~ dist
  .. ..- attr(*, ".Environment")=<environment: R_GlobalEnv> 
 $ co2.x1     : num 1
 $ co2.x2     : num 2
 $ co2.y1     : num 1
 $ co2.y2     : num 4

To avoid unintended results, in contrast to base R lists, elements cannot be added at new integer positions.

> l = list(a = 1, b = 2, c = 3)
> l[[4]] <- 4 # works
> l
$a
[1] 1

$b
[1] 2

$c
[1] 3

[[4]]
[1] 4
> ct = cont(a = 1, b = 2, c = 3)
> ct[[4]] <- 4 # fails
Error: index out of range (length = 3): 4

Replace values

Single or multiple value replacement works as usual.

> ct[[3]] <- 0
> ct[1:2] <- 0
> ct
[a = 0, b = 0, c = 0]

In contrast to base lists, containers can take a mix of numeric and character indices.

> ct[list("a", 3, "z")] <- 1
> ct
[a = 1, b = 0, c = 1, z = 1]

Another option for container object is to replace by value. For example, to replace the 0 by 100, can be achieved as follows.

> ct[[{0}]] <- 100
> ct
[a = 1, b = 100, c = 1, z = 1]

This works for any data type.

> co
[N = 5, data = <<data.frame(5x2)>>, ff = <<formula>>, co2 = [x = (1L 2L), y = (1 4)]]
> co[[{cars[1:5,]}]] <- cars
> co[[{co2}]] <- unpack(co2)
> co
[N = 5, data = <<data.frame(50x2)>>, ff = <<formula>>, co2 = (1 2 1 4)]

Extract

The standard operators to access elements also should be familiar to R users. 1

> ct[[1]]
[1] 1
> ct[1:3]
[a = 1, b = 100, c = 1]

As another option, you can pass any number of indices, possibly mixed as numeric and character.

> ct[1, 3, "z"]
[a = 1, c = 1, z = 1]
> ct[2:1, "a"]
[b = 100, a = 1, a = 1]

Inspect

Count the number of elements.

> count(ct, 0)
[1] 0
> count(ct, 1)
[1] 3

Check if container has an element

> has(co, cars)
[1] TRUE
> has(ct, cars)
[1] FALSE

or name.

> has_name(co, "a")
[1] FALSE
> has_name(ct, "a")
[1] TRUE

Use the apply family.

> sapply(co, is.numeric)
    N  data    ff   co2 
 TRUE FALSE FALSE  TRUE 
> sapply(ct, function(x) x + 1)
  a   b   c   z 
  2 101   2   2

  1. Note that the $ operator does not work.↩︎
